usage: See the manual page (man es) for a complete description of the commands. Type "help " for the documentation of . Available commands are: General commands help show this help exit, quit, q exit from the interactive shell trace, t enable/disable packet tracing verbose, v change verbosity level Connection establishment commands scan, s scan the network for easyshare servers connect connect to a remote server disconnect disconnect from a remote server open, o open a remote sharing (eventually discovering it) close, c close the remote sharing Transfer commands get, g get files and directories from the remote sharing put, p put files and directories in the remote sharing Local commands pwd show the name of current local working directory ls list local directory content l alias for ls -la tree list local directory contents in a tree-like format cd change local working directory mkdir create a local directory cp copy files and directories locally mv move files and directories locally rm remove files and directories locally exec, : execute an arbitrary command locally Remote commands rpwd show the name of current remote working directory rls list remote directory content rl alias for rls -la rtree list remote directory contents in a tree-like format rcd change remote working directory rmkdir create a remote directory rcp copy files and directories remotely rmv move files and directories remotely rrm remove files and directories remotely rexec, :: execute an arbitrary command remotely (disabled by default) since it will compromise server security Server information commands info, i show information about the remote server list list the sharings of the remote server ping test the connection with the remote server
help: COMMAND # alignment help - show the help of a command SYNOPSIS # alignment help [COMMAND] DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the help of COMMAND if specified, or show the list of commands if no COMMAND is given. Available commands are: : :: cd cp exec exit h help l ls mkdir mv pwd q quit rcd rcp rexec rl rls rm rmkdir rmv rpwd rrm rtree s scan t trace tree v verbose
h: COMMAND # alignment help - show the help of a command SYNOPSIS # alignment help [COMMAND] DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the help of COMMAND if specified, or show the list of commands if no COMMAND is given. Available commands are: : :: cd cp exec exit h help l ls mkdir mv pwd q quit rcd rcp rexec rl rls rm rmkdir rmv rpwd rrm rtree s scan t trace tree v verbose
exit: COMMAND # alignment exit - exit from the interactive shell SYNOPSIS # alignment exit quit q DESCRIPTION # alignment Exit from the interactive shell. Open connections are automatically closed.
quit: COMMAND # alignment exit - exit from the interactive shell SYNOPSIS # alignment exit quit q DESCRIPTION # alignment Exit from the interactive shell. Open connections are automatically closed.
q: COMMAND # alignment exit - exit from the interactive shell SYNOPSIS # alignment exit quit q DESCRIPTION # alignment Exit from the interactive shell. Open connections are automatically closed.
trace: COMMAND # alignment trace - enable/disable packet tracing SYNOPSIS # alignment trace [0 | 1] t [0 | 1] DESCRIPTION # alignment Show (1) or hide (0) the packets sent and received to and from the server for any operation. If no argument is given, toggle the packet tracing mode. EXAMPLES # alignment Here are some examples of data shown with the packet tracing on. { TODO: example }
t: COMMAND # alignment trace - enable/disable packet tracing SYNOPSIS # alignment trace [0 | 1] t [0 | 1] DESCRIPTION # alignment Show (1) or hide (0) the packets sent and received to and from the server for any operation. If no argument is given, toggle the packet tracing mode. EXAMPLES # alignment Here are some examples of data shown with the packet tracing on. { TODO: example }
verbose: COMMAND # alignment verbose - change verbosity level SYNOPSIS # alignment verbose [0 | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4] v [0 | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4]
v: COMMAND # alignment verbose - change verbosity level SYNOPSIS # alignment verbose [0 | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4] v [0 | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4]
pwd: COMMAND # alignment pwd - show the name of current local working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment pwd DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the name of current local working directory. The local working directory can be changed with the command cd. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rpwd" for the remote analogous.
ls: COMMAND # alignment ls - list local directory content SYNOPSIS # alignment ls [OPTION]... [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment List content of the local DIR or the current local directory if no DIR is specified. OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -s, --sort-size sort by size -S show files size SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rls" for the remote analogous.
tree: COMMAND # alignment tree - list local directory contents in a tree-like format SYNOPSIS # alignment tree [OPTION]... [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment List recursively, in a tree-like format, the local DIR or the current local directory if no DIR is specified. OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -d, --depth depth maximum display depth of tree -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -s, --sort-size sort by size -S show files size SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rtree" for the remote analogous.
cd: COMMAND # alignment cd - change local working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment cd [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the current local working directory to DIR or to the user's home directory if DIR is not specified. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rcd" for the remote analogous.
mkdir: COMMAND # alignment mkdir - create a local directory SYNOPSIS # alignment mkdir DIR DESCRIPTION # alignment Create the local directory DIR. Parent directories of DIR are automatically created when needed. If DIR already exists, it does nothing. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rmkdir" for the remote analogous.
cp: COMMAND # alignment cp - copy files and directories locally SYNOPSIS # alignment cp SOURCE DEST cp SOURCE... DIR DESCRIPTION # alignment Copy local SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or copy multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "cp SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will copied as DEST. - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be copied into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "cp SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be copied into it. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rcp" for the remote analogous.
mv: COMMAND # alignment mv - move files and directories locally SYNOPSIS # alignment mv SOURCE DEST mv SOURCE... DIR DESCRIPTION # alignment Move local SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or move multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "mv SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will moved as DEST. - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be moved into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "mv SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be moved into it. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rmv" for the remote analogous.
rm: COMMAND # alignment rm - remove files and directories locally SYNOPSIS # alignment rm [FILE]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Remove local FILEs. If a FILE is a directory, it will be removed recursively. If a FILE does not exists, it will be ignored. This commands never prompts: essentially acts like unix's rm -rf. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rrm" for the remote analogous.
exec: COMMAND # alignment exec - execute an arbitrary command locally SYNOPSIS # alignment exec COMMAND : COMMAND :COMMAND DESCRIPTION # alignment Executes an arbitrary COMMAND locally. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands without exiting the easyshare's shell. The command can be run either with "exec COMMAND", ": COMMAND" or ":COMMAND". EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> ls f1 f2 /tmp> exec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 /tmp> : echo "hello" > f3 /tmp> :cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rexec" for the remote analogous.
:: COMMAND # alignment exec - execute an arbitrary command locally SYNOPSIS # alignment exec COMMAND : COMMAND :COMMAND DESCRIPTION # alignment Executes an arbitrary COMMAND locally. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands without exiting the easyshare's shell. The command can be run either with "exec COMMAND", ": COMMAND" or ":COMMAND". EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> ls f1 f2 /tmp> exec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 /tmp> : echo "hello" > f3 /tmp> :cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rexec" for the remote analogous.
rpwd: COMMAND # alignment rpwd - show the name of current remote working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment rpwd SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the name of current remote working directory. The remote working directory can be changed with the command rcd. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help pwd" for the local analogous.
rls: COMMAND # alignment rls - list remote directory content SYNOPSIS # alignment rls [OPTION]... [DIR] rls [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [DIR] SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment List content of the remote DIR or the current remote directory if no DIR is specified. OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -s, --sort-size sort by size -S show files size SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help ls" for the local analogous.
rtree: COMMAND # alignment rtree - list remote directory contents in a tree-like format SYNOPSIS # alignment tree [OPTION]... [DIR] SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment List recursively, in a tree-like format, the remote DIR or the current remote directory if no DIR is specified OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -d, --depth depth maximum display depth of tree -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -s, --sort-size sort by size -S show files size SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help tree" for the local analogous.
rcd: COMMAND # alignment rcd - change remote working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment rcd [DIR] rcd [SHARING_LOCATION] [DIR] SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the current remote working directory to DIR or to the root of the current sharing if no DIR is specified. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open shared /tmp - remote.shared:/> rcd dir /tmp - remote.shared:/dir> rcd subdir /tmp - remote.shared:/dir/subdir> rcd /tmp - remote.shared:/> SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help cd" for the local analogous.
rmkdir: COMMAND # alignment rmkdir - create a remote directory SYNOPSIS # alignment rmkdir DIR rmkdir [SHARING_LOCATION] DIR SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Create the remote directory DIR. Parent directories of DIR are automatically created when needed. If DIR already exists, it does nothing. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open shared /tmp - remote.shared:/> rmkdir newdir /tmp - remote.shared:/> rcd newdir /tmp - remote.shared:/newdir> SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help mkdir" for the local analogous.
rcp: COMMAND # alignment rcp - copy files and directories remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rcp SOURCE DEST rcp SOURCE... DIR rcp [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE DEST rcp [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE... DIR SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Copy remote SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or copy multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "rcp SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will copied as DEST. - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be copied into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "rcp SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be copied into it. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open shared /tmp - remote.shared:/> rls f1 /tmp - remote.shared:/> rcp f1 f2 /tmp - remote.shared:/> rls f1 f2 /tmp> open shared /tmp - remote.shared:/> tree ├── dir ├── f1 └── f2 /tmp - remote.shared:/> rcp f1 f2 dir /tmp - remote.shared:/> rtree dir ├── dir │ ├── f1 │ └── f2 ├── f1 └── f2 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help cp" for the local analogous.
rmv: COMMAND # alignment rmv - move files and directories remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rmv SOURCE DEST rmv SOURCE... DIR rmv [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE DEST rmv [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE... DIR SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Move remote SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or move multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "rmv SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will moved as DEST. - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be moved into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "rmv SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be moved into it. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open shared /tmp - remote.shared:/> rls f1 /tmp - remote.shared:/> rmv f1 f2 /tmp - remote.shared:/> rls f2 /tmp> open shared /tmp - remote.shared:/> rtree ├── dir ├── f1 └── f2 /tmp - remote.shared:/> rmv f1 f2 dir /tmp - remote.shared:/> rtree dir └── dir ├── f1 └── f2 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help mv" for the local analogous.
rrm: COMMAND # alignment rmv - remove files and directories remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rm [FILE]... rm [SHARING_LOCATION] [FILE]... SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Remove remote FILEs. If a FILE is a directory, it will be removed recursively. If a FILE does not exists, it will be ignored. This commands never prompts: essentially acts like unix's rm -rf. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open shared /tmp - remote.shared:/> rls f1 f2 /tmp - remote.shared:/> rrm f2 /tmp - remote.shared:/> rls f1 /tmp> open shared /tmp - remote.shared:/> rtree ├── dir │ ├── f1 │ └── f2 └── f1 /tmp - remote.shared:/> rrm dir /tmp - remote.shared:/> tree └── f1 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rm" for the local analogous.
rexec: COMMAND # alignment rexec - execute an arbitrary command remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rexec COMMAND :: COMMAND ::COMMAND rexec [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND :: [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND ::[SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment THE SERVER REJECTS THIS COMMAND BY DEFAULT, UNLESS IT HAS BEEN MANUALLY ENABLED WITH THE SETTING "rexec=true" Executes an arbitrary COMMAND remotely. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands remotely, giving the client a kind of easy and plug-and-play shell. The command can be run either with "rexec COMMAND", ":: COMMAND" or "::COMMAND". EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> rls f1 f2 /tmp> rexec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 /tmp> :: echo "hello" > f3 /tmp> ::cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help exec" for the local analogous.
::: COMMAND # alignment rexec - execute an arbitrary command remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rexec COMMAND :: COMMAND ::COMMAND rexec [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND :: [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND ::[SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment THE SERVER REJECTS THIS COMMAND BY DEFAULT, UNLESS IT HAS BEEN MANUALLY ENABLED WITH THE SETTING "rexec=true" Executes an arbitrary COMMAND remotely. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands remotely, giving the client a kind of easy and plug-and-play shell. The command can be run either with "rexec COMMAND", ":: COMMAND" or "::COMMAND". EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> rls f1 f2 /tmp> rexec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 /tmp> :: echo "hello" > f3 /tmp> ::cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help exec" for the local analogous.
scan: COMMAND # alignment scan - scan the network for easyshare servers SYNOPSIS # alignment scan [OPTION]... s [OPTION]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Scan the network for easyshare server and reports the details of the sharings found. The discover is performed in broadcast in the network. The port on which the discover is performed is the one specified to es via -d port, or the default one if not specified. Only details about the sharings are shown, unless -L is given. OPTIONS # alignment -L show more details of both servers and sharings -l show more details of sharing EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> scan alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp bob-debian (192.168.1.185:12020) DIRECTORIES - music FILES - README.txt
s: COMMAND # alignment scan - scan the network for easyshare servers SYNOPSIS # alignment scan [OPTION]... s [OPTION]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Scan the network for easyshare server and reports the details of the sharings found. The discover is performed in broadcast in the network. The port on which the discover is performed is the one specified to es via -d port, or the default one if not specified. Only details about the sharings are shown, unless -L is given. OPTIONS # alignment -L show more details of both servers and sharings -l show more details of sharing EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> scan alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp bob-debian (192.168.1.185:12020) DIRECTORIES - music FILES - README.txt
